bottlenecks.title: Cultural sentiment
bottlenecks.description: Longevity research is a niche where people feel like they can't say what their actual goals are. Causes people to work on the wrong things / inefficient paths.

bottlenecks.title: Outdated Healthcare System
bottlenecks.description: We have a healthcare system designed in the 1800s that is reactionary to acute disease and the incentives are to maximize cost not health. We need an incentive structure that optimizes for health and lifespan via prevention of aging not treating the symptoms.

bottlenecks.title: Near-termism
bottlenecks.description: The majority of "longevity" work is attempts to find low hanging fruit that doesn't exist - current therapeutic stategies will mostly fail or have very little impact. A long-term mindset would but much more resources on technology development and more detailed characterization and modeling of aging.

bottlenecks.title: Nation state levels of funding (100's of billions)
bottlenecks.description: Apollo program was 250B + 400,000 people. Aging will likely take more resources

bottlenecks.title: Talent, and talent pipeline
bottlenecks.description: Very few people know that you can work on aging. Biology of aging isn't included in standard curriculum in high school / college.

bottlenecks.title: Perception
bottlenecks.description: The fact that the most funded seed startup in all of history could not reveal their financial backers suggests we need to do more to make funding longevity not just socially acceptable, but a moral imperative!

bottlenecks.title: Lack of gene delivery tools to do whole-body genetic engineering
Labor required to perform physiological mouse assays
Capital
bottlenecks.description: very hard to do science without funding

bottlenecks.title: HR
bottlenecks.description: very hard to do science without scientists

bottlenecks.title: Regulation
bottlenecks.description: very hard to do science when many experiments are not allowed

bottlenecks.title: Translational Research
bottlenecks.description: we are good at publish papers

bottlenecks.title: gain of function experiments
bottlenecks.description: not enough data on extended lifespan and correlated side effects (eg caloric restriction works in worms but they are less mobile and lethargic, prob immune compromised)

bottlenecks.title: step wise organ wise extension of lifespan/functional span
bottlenecks.description: express telomerade eg in one tissue that is age limiting, then another, then another and show additive effect

bottlenecks.title: current theories are nonsense except for antagonistic pleiotropy
bottlenecks.description: we need equations or formulaic approaches. from protein damage, to dna damage, to ros to.wathever single.aspect we focus on, we lose 2 things: 1) the perspecti e thst aging integrated and 2) the side effects of tweaking single parameters. also i doubt an engineered organism that libes longer will have a chance to compete with wildtype in the wild. Its Evolution and natural selection baby.

bottlenecks.title: Cheap and fast invivo testing
bottlenecks.description: Not democratised access to both academics and commerical entities

bottlenecks.title: Extensive computational approach
bottlenecks.description: You need to derive insights test hypothesise in the dry lab long before the wet one

bottlenecks.title: FDA approved clinical proxies
bottlenecks.description: We need concrete aging clinical trials, right now its bypassed with other indications

bottlenecks.title: Awareness on the part of clinicians, regulators and general public
Path to market given today's regulatory environment
Trained hands to work on projects
bottlenecks.description: Limited funding, federal and state pay caps for postdocs and graduate students, limited supply of interested students

bottlenecks.title: Close-minded funding and reviewers limiting avenues of research
bottlenecks.description: The vast majority of aging research are variations on the same 3-4 topics in the same 3-5 systems; while the most radical breakthroughs are most likely to come from alternative, unexplored sources (non-model organisms, other white elephants), both public and private funders are reluctant to fund these lines of research.

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: A bottleneck as fundamental to science as aging is to biology. This is both for basic science funding as well as translational funding.

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: No NIH institute or program is focusing on aging itself

bottlenecks.title: Luck of funding to produce preliminary data
bottlenecks.description: Longevity experiments are very long and expensive, thus it is impossible to run them to produce preliminary data without substantial funding. You cannot obtain substantial funding without preliminary data. This vicious cycle is specifically hard to overcome in aging research due to the very high cost of longevity studies.

bottlenecks.title: Aging is not considered a disease
bottlenecks.description: One big obstacle in the development of anti-aging therapy is the fact that aging is not considered a disease by FDA and anti-aging drugs can be marketed only against aging-associated conditions, rather than aging itself. It is often the case that anti-aging therapy is not competitive as compared with other drugs targeting specific age-associated conditions even if it is highly efficient in slowing down aging itself.

bottlenecks.title: No funding is available.
bottlenecks.description: NIA's funding rate is too low.

bottlenecks.title: No clear goal of the government funding agency in advancing aging research.
There's not sufficient support from the society to aging research.
Shortage of creative and rigorous talent working on aging
bottlenecks.description: Throughout all of the moonshot aging projects I have encountered, they have shared the same glaring problem that serves as the biggest impediment to success: lack of top 1% talent (in terms of creativity, rigor, and skill) to pull off said moonshot project. Need talent in all positions accelerating the space (biologists, engineers, operators, computer scientists, lobbyists, investors, family offices, etc

bottlenecks.title: The math problem - not enough resources to solve aging
bottlenecks.description: https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/math-problem-sid-efromovich-1e/

bottlenecks.title: Methods to rejuvenate the aging brain (such as controlled tissue turnover)
bottlenecks.description: The brain is the most important organ for aging/continuity of self. Everything else could be replaced like parts.

bottlenecks.title: Data Availability and Sharing
bottlenecks.description: We are creating biomarkers of longevity and in order to make these better we need more data available.  Some algorithms like GrimAge still have not be released publicly.

bottlenecks.title: Disagreement in basic definitions of aging
bottlenecks.description: When people mention terms like aging, biological age or rejuvenation, they typically talk about different things. This difference in interpretation causes disagreement that confuses researchers and makes them easier to disagree on detailed topics of different interventions.

bottlenecks.title: Restrictions on medication development to target aging
bottlenecks.description: The question whether Aging itself is a disease is controversial. This affects the policy and many medications designed to target aging has to be focused on specific age-related diseases rather than targeting the functional decline related to the age

bottlenecks.title: Over advertising of potential interventions and Lack of commonly agreed key assessment standards
bottlenecks.description: People  don't have a common way to assess age-related functional decline. They use their own readouts in their own research and claim that something works. No commonly agreed standard in the field is reached

bottlenecks.title: Lack of funding
bottlenecks.description: Hard to compete for $ against majority of fraudulent claims and bad science, judged by VC types ignorant about basic biology and medicine

bottlenecks.title: Lack of data
bottlenecks.description: No data format or quality standards in the field

bottlenecks.title: Knowledge dissemination
bottlenecks.description: Conferences and journals are flooded by same players pushing commerce oriented stories of packaging bad science as products

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: To get funding from NIH we need to first demonstrate that a natural model for longevity (e.g. bats) models human aging. Do this requires funding, but is too high risk for NIH

bottlenecks.title: Samples
bottlenecks.description: The most interesting natural models for aging are species that are long-lived and don't tolerate captivity. Collecting high quality samples is challenging and requires collaboration.

bottlenecks.title: Compute
bottlenecks.description: Comparative genomics is very promising path forward for aging research, but is computationally extremely demanding. We need access to data, expertise and funding to building the resources for the community to utilize evolution as a tool for investigating aging.

bottlenecks.title: Too much focus on the same genes/pathways
bottlenecks.description: While these pathways are important, they fail in populations because we don't understand supporting mechanisms

bottlenecks.title: Lots of opinion leaders with biased views of biology of aging
bottlenecks.description: Very little true scrutiny of various hypotheses.

bottlenecks.title: Hard to do studies in mammals due to length of study and high cost
bottlenecks.description: Obvious

bottlenecks.title: No true surrogate markers for biological age.
bottlenecks.description: Existing biomarkers are flawed.

bottlenecks.title: Data portability
bottlenecks.description: The labs generating the research are usually not very data savy and they are asked to create files that are machine readable. We end up with unfortunate structures that make it impossible to collate data without lengthy manual curation.

bottlenecks.title: Data availability
bottlenecks.description: There are large numbers of repositories and it is surprising there is no database where someone can type queries and receive as an output all the data sources containing this type of data.

bottlenecks.title: Data quality
bottlenecks.description: There are published datasets of low quality. This forces one to only believe datasets from known labs.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of understanding of the mechanistic causes of aging
bottlenecks.description: Few studies have been conducted that identify causative factors in aging. Many merely identify factors that are associated with aging.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of consensus on foundational issues in aging research. There is broad disagreement on what is aging, what is rejuvenation, what is development, when aging begins, etc
bottlenecks.description: To work collaboratively and move the field forward, we need some level of agreement and common ground

bottlenecks.title: Negative results are rarely published
bottlenecks.description: It is not attractive to journals to publish negative results. Furthermore, negative results can negatively impact biotech companies. To efficiently design therapies that target aging and work in vivo, we need to know which therapies fail and why. We also need to know the limitations of therapies that work in some regards but not in others

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: In our case it's more difficult as we do not have co-founders members who are from an Ivy League University.

bottlenecks.title: Costs
bottlenecks.description: The costs to accomplish non human primate and clinical trials are so high that one is forced to raise a large series A in which many founders dilute down considerably in their  equity holding.

bottlenecks.title: Abuse by Predecessors
bottlenecks.description: I have yet to meet investors who actually understand fully biology of aging so their decision to invest are based on the comfort of stellar academic background of founders. This has allowed some start ups to raise very large amounts and then created mediocre results to create a bad reputation for longevity start ups. One company raised $400 million went IPO on Nasdaq another raised $600+ million last at $12 billion valuation followed by lackluster Phase I results. Except for Alkahest and BioAge who have shown some Phase I/II success no one else is showing any such promise. Even after a decade not a single longevity drug has achieved regulatory approval and is being prescribed.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of principled way to choose the next intervention to try
bottlenecks.description: E.g. having computational models similar to PerturbNet or scFormer that given a desired cell state (young) predict what to do to the cell. This requires a lot of data collection

bottlenecks.title: Not enough Human Biology
bottlenecks.description: Too much emphasis on non-human models that don't translate

bottlenecks.title: Inappropriate clinical trials
bottlenecks.description: Need more sophisticated clinical studies

bottlenecks.title: Lack of Insight into intervention mechanisms
bottlenecks.description: Too little insight into how interventions may benefit humans

bottlenecks.title: geroscience clinical trials for off patent drugs
bottlenecks.description: most of the best candidates for translation to humans now are off-patent, but there is limited appetite for funding necessary clinical trials

bottlenecks.title: stagnation of geroscience interventions
bottlenecks.description: the most effective geroscience intervention is still caloric restriction - nearly 100 years later; nobody in the field is doing unbiased larges-scale screening for new interventions/combinationsn with greater effect sizes and a disproportionate amount of funding is being put toward studying interventions with tiny effect sizes (e.g. isocaloric intermittent fasting, time restricted feeding, NAD precursors, etc.)

bottlenecks.title: poor/fraudulent communication to the general public
bottlenecks.description: many of the most popular personalities (e.g. David Sinclair, Aubrey deGrey) with the widest audiences portray the field in a way that causes many people, particularly those in high level academic and government positions, to view the field as full of snake oil and fraud

bottlenecks.title: unifying molecular mechanisms of aging
bottlenecks.description: The field is scattered with a million ways to impact age progression.

bottlenecks.title: clinical trials
bottlenecks.description: cost, time (safety, efficacy)

bottlenecks.title: pre-clinical trials
bottlenecks.description: cost

bottlenecks.title: impact of each epigenetic factor
bottlenecks.description: understanding

bottlenecks.title: difficulty to apply results from non-human studies
focus on drug development for anti-aging
FDA pathway
bottlenecks.description: Reliable way to secure roadmap for clinical funding

bottlenecks.title: Early stage investment
bottlenecks.description: Getting a preclinical package together

bottlenecks.title: Speculative grants for non-University research
bottlenecks.description: To explore ideas in-silico and identify targets

bottlenecks.title: insufficient metrics
bottlenecks.description: no way to tell how effective a particular treatment is

bottlenecks.title: most functional medicine physicians are prey to herd mentality
bottlenecks.description: can't trust doctors, then how to achieve longevity escape velocity?

bottlenecks.title: FDA
bottlenecks.description: slowing down time to market and escalating the cost of drug development

bottlenecks.title: FDA
bottlenecks.description: Aging not regarded a a disease

bottlenecks.title: funding
bottlenecks.description: obvious

bottlenecks.title: people with fresh insights
bottlenecks.description: huge effort on AI/data crunching will yield diminishing returns

bottlenecks.title: need clearer phenotypes of ageing
bottlenecks.description: aged humans regarded as a homogeneous population. Definition of sub-categories may lead to clearer questions/answers

bottlenecks.title: small amount of published results on my research topic
bottlenecks.description: not enough people executing experiments in the field

bottlenecks.title: small number of clinical trials targeting aging rather than diseases
bottlenecks.description: aging is not classified as a disease, also limited number of aging biomarkers

bottlenecks.title: lack of giant ageing omics databases for human data
bottlenecks.description: human data is often protected, donor age is not always available in public databases

bottlenecks.title: Difficult to tell what treatments will work in humans
Lack of good human models of aging
Publicly available datasets are rare and small
getting people outside the aging field to take the field seriously
getting people inside the aging field to consider alternatives to the aging as an accumulation of damage theory
Funding
bottlenecks.description: Funding is constrained and tends to be going to quite conservative projects.

bottlenecks.title: Skilled labor
bottlenecks.description: The field needs more people with proper Geroscience training in it. The current interest in the space should yield dividends but it will take 5-8 years for the talent pool to deepen.

bottlenecks.title: Tools and integration
bottlenecks.description: The field of aging is limited by the quality of its resources and reagents. Higher quality reagents are desperately needed. Furthermore, more integration is needed for the analysis of big data in aging to parse out the wheat from the chaff.

bottlenecks.title: the fragmentation/lack of interconnection in the aging field
bottlenecks.description: since the aging field is new, there's not much interconnection, and so there are lots of small pockets of people who are weakly--if at all--connected with other groups of people in the field. this makes it hard for us to find them, for them to find us, and for information and opportunities to circulate more generally. it also, i suspect, decreases retention for the field, as the level of difficulty in finding community and building peer relationships is too high for many who end up being dispirited and leave

bottlenecks.title: my network
bottlenecks.description: i moved into the aging field with literally 0 aging people (that I know of) in my network. i've had to build a network from scratch, and it's going well, but it's taken longer than i expected--partially due to the first bottleneck

bottlenecks.title: resources (especially time)
bottlenecks.description:
i meet a lot of people that i can help--even with my network being in a pretty nascent state. but i often don't have the resources (especially time & energy) to help. and helping them would go a long way in building a relationship and building trust with them so they can help us

one interesting example of this: groups researching biology of aging around the world who are extremely loosely--if at all--connected to the field that's coalescing now. there are probably 7-10 different groups at the University of Sao Paulo studying biology of aging, and I'm connected with the right people there.

my pretty nonscientific hypothesis is that if i were able to integrate them into the field by making introductions to peers, mentors, and funders AND could give them even a pretty small amount of $, there could be significant downstream positive effects.

to illustrate a piece of that... one of my candidates for Talent Bridge is about to finish her PhD at perhaps the most prestigious research institute in Brazil. she has won 5 scholarships and awards. has clear star potential to everyone who knows her. but she has ZERO first author publications due to lack of resources.

not only does this mean we do not benefit from what could be good research, but it also means she doesn't build experience and credibility and won't be able to move forward in her career. it makes it harder for us to help her relocate to the US. and odds are, she won't contribute much to the world nearly as much as she is capable of.

bottlenecks.title: Time
bottlenecks.description: mouse lifespan experiments take ~30 month

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: No specialised funding for ageing in the UK - no NIA equivalent

bottlenecks.title: Resources for collaboration
bottlenecks.description: No easy way to get joint funding

bottlenecks.title: Translation
bottlenecks.description: Fundamental disconnect for most academics between bench and clinic

bottlenecks.title: Drug development expertise
bottlenecks.description: Academic labs studying aging do not know how to develop drugs.

bottlenecks.title: Target validation
bottlenecks.description: Relatively few validated aging targets.

bottlenecks.title: Reproducibility
bottlenecks.description: Many papers in the space are not reproducible.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of effective user interfaces/packaging for ML/Data Science Software
bottlenecks.description: Experts in our field with the most experience are generally from older generations, and cannot set up environments/utilize CLI software out of the box. This leads to a severe underutilization of the most effective tools that are out there, so that 1. data analysis is never done effectively, 2. experiments are not designed with a data-first mindset initially (as the endpoint remains qualitative). Furthermore, even with CLI-competent users, sometimes, setting up the environment is impossible and therefore the tool is never used.

bottlenecks.title: Insufficient data analysis leading to erroneous spend
bottlenecks.description:
Modern data analysis techniques can elicit if targets either slow aging, or reduce all-cause mortality at all ages but do not slow the rate, i.e. : https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-022-34515-y

Many therapeutics are mislabeled as anti-aging, with a ton of $$ spend dedicated to these dead-ends. Better data analysis, data-first thinking, and talk between data scientists and biologists could ameliorate this problem.

bottlenecks.title: Irreproducibility
bottlenecks.description: Mostly in senescence work, a majority of the body of literature is not reproducible

bottlenecks.title: Length of experimental observation required to determine effect of a treatment.
Difficulty and cost of clinical development of anti-ageing treatments.
Lack of agreed criteria for, and difficulty of objectively determiing healthpsan.
I lack credibility
bottlenecks.description: I dropped out of school to start a software business that I have since sold. For this reason, I do not lack finances or freedom, but have trouble getting my ideas out through standard academic mediums.

bottlenecks.title: I need collaborators
bottlenecks.description: I am in the midwest. I suspect this would be less of an issue if I moved to one of the coasts.

bottlenecks.title: Stigma
bottlenecks.description: I'm working in Alzheimer's and Dementia and there is still a lot of stigma associated with the disease which results in lack of diagnoses and limited possibility for interventions, participation in trials, etc

bottlenecks.title: Drug discovery
bottlenecks.description: Misalignment between academic grant funding and publication pressure with discovery science.

bottlenecks.title: Mammalian validation
bottlenecks.description: Mouse studies are costly and slow. Lack of translational model systems to validate interventions in mammalian systems.

bottlenecks.title: Investor financing
bottlenecks.description: A large inflow of resources spread across multiple approaches is necessary to meaningfully accelerate longevity biotechnology.

bottlenecks.title: Obtaining NIH grants
bottlenecks.description: combination of beauracratic system that is gamed, implicit/explicit bias and anti-basic research bias

bottlenecks.title: Nepotism
bottlenecks.description: this may not be specific to science

bottlenecks.title: Leaving my current non aging related career
bottlenecks.description: Lack of time to plan career move, salary paycut, relocation to the bay area

bottlenecks.title: pharma partnership
bottlenecks.description: they want more data, we need a partner to generate more data, feedback loop

bottlenecks.title: pitching a non-product
bottlenecks.description: we're a discovery platform, it's hard to pitch to investors when you don't have a consumer-ready product yet; it's hard to explain to researchers that we are vertically integrated (from lab to analysis)

bottlenecks.title: treatment naive patients
bottlenecks.description: we have organic growth, but people drop into the healthcare system once issues arise, so it's hard to grow our following with early-diagnosed autoimmune patients

bottlenecks.title: Systems Bio modeling
bottlenecks.description: The field seems to be relatively ignored, imo.  Aging is very much a system-wide process, while most approaches seem to be piecemeal - and many promising new drugs fail, because they didn't adequately take system-wide interactions into account

bottlenecks.title: Public understanding
bottlenecks.description: The public at large is still painfully unaware of recent advances in Longevity Science - in 2020, even my coworkers at a large pharma were incredibly ignorant!  (at least until their CSO resigned, and became CEO of Altos Labs!!)

bottlenecks.title: Big Pharma and small companies working together
bottlenecks.description: I like to make the analogy of NASA + SpaceX

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: Aging is very underfunded and we are in a recession so VC is particularly hard to raise right now. Also the process of raising capital is super time consuming and inefficient.

bottlenecks.title: Cheaper and more clinical trials
bottlenecks.description: Clinical trials cost $2B. That means we can't run many of them. We need safe and thorough ways to run cheaper trials.

bottlenecks.title: Time
bottlenecks.description: I need a clone of myself

bottlenecks.title: Challenges in technology development
bottlenecks.description: Our goal is to develop new technologies. There are lots of challenges to overcome.

bottlenecks.title: Finding applications for technology that hasn't been developed yet
bottlenecks.description: We think our technology can help understand aging, but it will need to be proven.

bottlenecks.title: Talent
bottlenecks.description: Finding the right people with both technical skills and culture fit.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of clarity on FDA regulatory process for aging drugs
Customer engagement
bottlenecks.description: Anti aging perceived as a wish not based in reality

bottlenecks.title: Regulation
bottlenecks.description: Health claims for experimental technologies prohibited

bottlenecks.title: commercialization
bottlenecks.description: Requires critical mass of adoption to amortize COGS

bottlenecks.title: I believe there is a lack of funding in areas of science that are not 'hot-topics.' While I'm not working directly in academia or industry, I've noticed that funding continues to be an issue.
bottlenecks.description: I believe it's because under-focused topics seem more risky as investments.

bottlenecks.title: Too few people care about aging
bottlenecks.description: Even though we as an industry are doing a better job than we used to, the scale is not there

bottlenecks.title: Not enough money
bottlenecks.description: Again it is way better than it is used to be, but we would need way more to do meaningful progress and test a variety of approaches

bottlenecks.title: Aging clocks are too noisy
bottlenecks.description: It is not a problem per se, but now the DNAm and other clocks are being positioned as a tool for personal use, which they are clearly not (because of high noise). This can be a detriment to the industry

bottlenecks.title: Difficulties in getting funding for whole animal physiology research
Limited number of potential collaborators at my institution
Age-related decline in ability and willingness to "push"
Models that can capture human aging
bottlenecks.description: Mouse, worms or fly models are not ideal

bottlenecks.title: Limitation of using multiple inputs at the same time in existing models
bottlenecks.description: Human aging is a complex process that is affected by many environmental and internal conditions

bottlenecks.title: We need to look at the 99% of the genome that doesn't code for protein
bottlenecks.description: We haven't gotten anywhere just looking at the protein-coding genes.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of consensus on fundamentals of aging
bottlenecks.description: We do not understand what aging *is*, biologically. I think this is the single greatest bottleneck in the aging research community. Different people have differing conceptions of what aging is, and so many potentially fruitful discussions among researchers are stifled because of the lack of agreement on what aging is and isn't.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of quality datasets, specifically large-scale, longitudinal human aging datasets.
bottlenecks.description: We need quality datasets to understand what is actually going on during the aging process. I think the focus for both animal and human researchers needs to turn to generation of high-quality, highly resolved, longitudinal datasets of individuals followed over the whole life course. The Dunedin study is a very good model for what we need more of.

bottlenecks.title: We need to better connect the computational aging biologists to the "wet lab" aging biologists. These communities have diverse skill sets that could be better combined to achieve more synergy in aging research.
bottlenecks.description: This is partially related to my 2nd bottleneck: computational people need better data to be generated by experimental people, experimental people need to better design their studies to be more useful to computational people.

bottlenecks.title: Public awareness of potential
bottlenecks.description: Lack of credible source intro plus Fear of getting hope up

bottlenecks.title: Finance directed at aging diseases oblivious to underlying common biology of aging
bottlenecks.description: Continuing as was

bottlenecks.title: Money
bottlenecks.description: Effort

bottlenecks.title: Automation of previously done methods.
bottlenecks.description: So many things in the cell culture lab, mouse lab, and computational modeling are done before and repetitive and should be automated by robotics or AI, or other solutions.

bottlenecks.title: Sustainable funding for research
bottlenecks.description: Tiny/short foundation/philanthropic organization grants and larger NIH grants miss the mark. If you want to make a real impact, find a way to generate SUSTAINABLE funding for research. Huge time and effort wasted on applying for patchwork funding. Happy to elaborate this is a big focus of my own philanthropic work.

bottlenecks.title: Identify a reliable Biomarker
bottlenecks.description: The agin process is very noisy so biomarkers are most of the times not robust enough

bottlenecks.title: Estimate the efficacy and the safety of treatments
bottlenecks.description: The phenotype are often confounding

bottlenecks.title: measuring lifespan
bottlenecks.description: hard to take care of animals for a long time

bottlenecks.title: finding an intervention for longevity
bottlenecks.description: we still don't know what we should target

bottlenecks.title: Lack of understanding of the space by politicians and influencers
No financial incentives to develop longevity medicines for companies
Lack of funding for basic research
Lack of 'moonshot' projects
bottlenecks.description: Academia is not incentivising such high-risk / high reward research

bottlenecks.title: Public awareness
bottlenecks.description: Aging not considered a disease or problem

bottlenecks.title: lack of long-term datasets
bottlenecks.description: we often have scarce data points from untraceable sources

bottlenecks.title: standardized methodologies to study aging across the tree of life
bottlenecks.description: comparing results if often challenging during to the different methodologies used to study aging in different taxa

bottlenecks.title: Time it takes to age samples
Structures of academic science making it difficult to pursue the coolest ideas
easy access to clinical samples
bottlenecks.description: academic labs have lots of great ideas that could be quickly tested if getting clinical samples weren't so difficult

bottlenecks.title: increasing expectations that academic labs will carry out safety and efficacy clinical trials
bottlenecks.description: industry increasingly only wants ideas that are not risky - leaves academics to carry all risks, even if there are no scientific questions left (e.g., just safety and clinical trials)

bottlenecks.title: IN general, the gulf between academic labs and industry
bottlenecks.description: most findings from academic labs will not result in forward progress - which is why we're stuck re-treading metformin, rapamycin, etc instead of finding new longevity drugs

bottlenecks.title: Difficulty of implementing complicated protocols
bottlenecks.description: Cost, poorly written protocols, lack of instrumentation, difficulty of solo learning techniques

bottlenecks.title: endpoints
bottlenecks.description: time (hard to measure successful longevity interventions)

bottlenecks.title: tools
bottlenecks.description: delivery (potency, toxicity, specificity), precise editing

bottlenecks.title: FDA recognition
bottlenecks.description: need to consider aging as something worth / possible to treat

bottlenecks.title: We need to the effect of natural genetic variation on response to putative interventions.
bottlenecks.description: This is a major bottleneck, as there is less work on this problem, and so far has been little interest by NIH in funding this problem (though they are trying to ameliorate this problem). This is critically important--the few studies out there on genetic variation and interventions show that for *any* intervention known to increase lifespan, there are genotypes that either don't respond or response *negatively*.

bottlenecks.title: Epidemiologists have identified environmental factors that can alter human lifespan by many years. The biology-focused geroscience community pays little attention to this. Biologists and epidemiologists/environmental risk experts need to work more closely together.
bottlenecks.description: Little support for cross-disciplinary work in this area, and historical lack of contact between molecular biologists and epidemiologists.

bottlenecks.title: personnel with dual expertise (or interest in developing such) in computational biology and epidemiology
bottlenecks.description: not sure. could be that biotech is sucking up all the postdocs. could be that there is just not enough comp bio expertise in api-oriented PhDs

bottlenecks.title: longitudinal biological data on large samples of humans
bottlenecks.description: there are too few public-domain datasets that observe the natural course of human aging in large numbers of individuals. there are a number of datasets that could help us make rapid progress. but they are closely held and accessing them is intensely bureaucratic and time consuming.

bottlenecks.title: mindset
bottlenecks.description:
My position in the field is quite unique as I propose a model that contradicts the mainstream ideas that most people believe. I think our arguments are the strongest but somehow people think that finding the exact nature of aging is less important than doing blind drug screens and omics.

I am not sure my case is representative.

bottlenecks.title: lack of sufficient money for research
Time in cell culture
bottlenecks.description: Limiting factor for testing a large number of experimental conditions

bottlenecks.title: Limited foundational knowledge, especially in a structured and centralized format
Research in Aging is siloed.
bottlenecks.description: Funding is in deep novel science

bottlenecks.title: Return On Investment analysis are few is any
bottlenecks.description: Real world data takes time. Suggest simulating results and forecast ?

bottlenecks.title: Catching Public Imagination.
bottlenecks.description: Requires lay person terms to educate and create concerted and coordinated media, policy and gov outreach

bottlenecks.title: Ability to digest and understand the science
bottlenecks.description: Don't come from a science background, big learning curve

bottlenecks.title: As an investor, the lack of an aging indication for FDA approval limits the scale/speed of development
Precise definition of (biological) aging -- or lack of a "gold standard"
bottlenecks.description: It defines the overarching goal, the target of interventions, and how we measure progress.

bottlenecks.title: (Stemming from a lack of a clear definition...) Tools to measures changes in aging
bottlenecks.description: Epigenetic clocks are a start, but they are far from perfect. For example, how quickly can biological aging be slowed, halted, or reversed? Our biomarkers should reflect that time-scale. Another example, does aging happen at an organism-level or tissue-level or cell-level (e.g., Can someone's brain be aging faster than their liver?)

bottlenecks.title: Greater translational work (e.g., studying senescence in human tissue) and more validation and benchmarking studies
bottlenecks.description: There is a lot of hype in the field right now. Independent validation of findings across species and populations would help distinguish the reproducible findings.

bottlenecks.title: Donations
bottlenecks.description: My organization, Lifespan.io, is doing a lot of important work in the media and advocacy field, but like many NGOs, we're underfunded. More donations would allow us to extend our presence and reach.

bottlenecks.title: Conference passes
bottlenecks.description: Some conferences are reluctant to provide media passes, not to mention covering expenses, which hampers our ability to provide coverage and amplification.

bottlenecks.title: Paper access
bottlenecks.description: Journals have convoluted ways of providing free access to the media or none at all.

bottlenecks.title: Access to NHP and human brains
bottlenecks.description: I'm primarily interested in brain rejuvenation. The testing platforms for brain interventions still feel very nascent.

bottlenecks.title: Robust biomarkers for different organs
bottlenecks.description: I assume that this will come from improving proteomics.

bottlenecks.title: Access to consistent fetal brain tissue
bottlenecks.description: A cell therapy that's particularly exciting needs access to genetically identical fetal brain tissue samples on a scheduled basis.

bottlenecks.title: Getting FDA to classify aging as a diesease
Building biomarkers that can act as endpoints in diseases
Lack of aging biomarker beyond methylation clock
insufficient funding for research, especially long-term animal and human studies
bottlenecks.description: overall, society has invested to little into the scientific community, especially for aging research. NIA was one of the latest established and least funded (outside of Alheimer's specific funds) of the NIH institutes.

bottlenecks.title: misconceptions about the purpose of aging research
bottlenecks.description: pop culture focus on billionaires living forever, as opposed to what will be the real impact of understanding aging - everyone living more healthy lives and reducing the overall burden of chronic disease on human society

bottlenecks.title: regulatory processes that do not recognize and do not provide adequate trial opportunities for aging-related interventions, many of which will need to be preventative, and many of which will not be focused on a single (classically defined) disease/indication
bottlenecks.description: regulatory bodies and processes were established before real recognition of the importance of aging to overall human and societal health - we lack metrics, biomarkers and even definitions that would be useful for assessing antigeronic interventions.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of understanding the importance of mitochondrial genetics.
bottlenecks.description: Dominance of the Mendelian paradigm in hypotheses and experimental design.

bottlenecks.title: Beta amyloid theory of age related disease.
bottlenecks.description: Lack of support for alternative hypotheses.

bottlenecks.title: Human Donor Cell Access
bottlenecks.description: Human Bone Marrow from healthy young and aged Donors is not easy to obtain for biotec and research

bottlenecks.title: Targeting the ECM
bottlenecks.description: Extracellular Matrix Aging is challenging to address given current non-invasive drug delivery vehicles or surgery, implants, infusions, none offering effective treatment options yet

bottlenecks.title: We need more Scientific Operators in longgevity biotec, and their salaries are too low compared to administrative and executive levels
bottlenecks.description: Performing the research remains to imperative to achieve breakthroughs

bottlenecks.title: Definition of aging
bottlenecks.description: To design the experiment, it is important to set the definition or criteria. But currently, it is difficult to decide what I should look at to evaluate aging.

bottlenecks.title: Aging model?
bottlenecks.description: Some stresses are known to accelerate aging, but not sure if  they really reflect aging. And as same as described above.

bottlenecks.title: Contract
bottlenecks.description: I understand that it's depend on country or institute, but it is hard for 3-year-contract pod docs to work on 3-year-lifespan animal models.

bottlenecks.title: Connections to biotech interested in age-associated diseases
Lack of funding
bottlenecks.description: Research is expensive

bottlenecks.title: biomarkers
bottlenecks.description: need to quantify aging and rejuvenation

bottlenecks.title: We need AI-driven solutions to understand and deconvolute the complexity of the aging process.
Lack of network dedicated to solving challenges in field of aging
Lack of human samples for specific age related diseases.
bottlenecks.description: Difficult to find sources. Often samples not completely labeled, or no chart information.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of model systems that fully recapitulate human disease.
bottlenecks.description: Species differences in aging process, or genetics not similar enough.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of longitudinal studies for disease.
bottlenecks.description: May studies are comprehensive for human disease, but lack age specific time points.

bottlenecks.title: Obtaining aged samples
bottlenecks.description: methods require significant study material, obtain very little per mouse

bottlenecks.title: long times required for aging studies

The research directions most likely to result in very rapid or very dramatic advances are at best orthogonal to the most fundable (or even at all fundable) ones within academia, and many of the most promising will still be too early / basic for a company or short-term return driven funding model. Attempts to provide alternative academic funding that are not on par with the size of the NIH R01 grants (~375K/y for 5 years)  that are the benchmark for career survival in academia are excellent catalysts with great potential use cases but cannot incentivize academics away from more NIH-fundable research in the long term. This is not a matter of their personal choice but their of continued employment within this system as it exists currently.

The overlap between (A) reviewers who are able to think outside of the box and are not incentivized strongly away from simply thinking broadly about how to move this field forward in the best / fastest way, and those reviewers (B) who know the technical aspects deeply (things that have been tried and failed, including e.g. things that have never been retracted but have been extremely hard to reproduce, things that are considered settled but are perhaps still not well understood, etc.) is quite limited. There is a lot of potential talent and resources becoming more and more interested in this question but they are sometimes tenuously connected to the best, most unbiased repositories of existing hard-won lessons. Further complicationg this, for any non-tenured academic or other precarious researcher, when useful information might be poorly received by a more senior colleague (e.g. the information conflicts with a finding of theirs, etc.) this communication to outsiders might sometimes be muted, at best.
Talent and interest
bottlenecks.description: There's lots of amazing people working on cutting-edge things in other fields (artificial intelligence, for example) that could contribute greatly to longevity if they became interested in it and if the right incentives were put in place. Despite the fact that these people may be highly technically skilled, there is also a barrier to entry (knowledge of biology, lower compensation, harder/more long-term problems, etc...)

bottlenecks.title: Experimental speed and throughput
bottlenecks.description: Sam Rodriques recently wrote a really cool article that discusses this topic a bit (https://www.sam-rodriques.com/post/why-is-progress-in-biology-so-slow). Longevity experiments naturally take time (especially if lifespan needs to be observed). Progress is limited by the number of well-designed experiments that can be run. For example, if running a reprogramming experiment takes you 20 days and your lab is only equipped to run one of these experiments at a time, then you are majorly limited by your iteration speed. I think the key here is automation, but this is very difficult to properly establish end-to-end.

bottlenecks.title: Knowledge gates
bottlenecks.description: This one is more philosophical, but I believe there is so much knowledge that different entities hold that could dramatically speed up global research efforts if that knowledge was shared. While academia is a culture of sharing (through the paper system), it's historically been uncommon for biotechs to share their progress / hurdles. While this would require a significant shift in perception, I believe this would be ultimately net good for the world. The same can be said for negative results in academia: if more of these were shared and exposed, I reckon a lot of time would be saved in the future.

bottlenecks.title: Resolving temporal dynamics (i.e. finding first actors and other causal players)
bottlenecks.description:
Very few, large, high-quality, high-resolution longitudinal human data sets are available that span a biologically relevant periods of time (i.e. encapsulating prodromal and disease free states, or young individuals).
In tissue culture, experiments are not routinely done to even attempt to mimic low-grade, chronic stressors and measure outputs longitudinally

bottlenecks.title: Limited existing statistics and mathematical tools to evaluate complex state changes in various "omics" data
bottlenecks.description: We are still limited, as wet lab scientists, to using models that primarily are limited to bidirectional data and pairwise comparisons ( (i.e too much focus on what individual gene goes up and down, instead of which homeostatic feedback loops are perturbed)

bottlenecks.title: Advanced cell culture models and interventions that recapitulate aging in relevant ways
bottlenecks.description: Related to my first point, but reiterating because this is just a lack of effort.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of centralized&compelete database for aging-related omic data
Hard and slow to apply established human data (e.g., FHS)
Most of the employment and collaboration opportunities are concentrated in the US
bottlenecks.description: Harder to transition to the field without relocating to US

bottlenecks.title: There is a lack of basic science research in aging biology.
bottlenecks.description: Not enough researchers/labs working in the field of aging biology. Those that work is centered in a few nations, despite the global nature of the aging problem. Lack of funds- aging research is time consuming and expensive.

bottlenecks.title: Common public misconceptions: e.g., Aging is unavoidable and there is nothing that can be done about it; aging research focuses on finding ways to look younger.
bottlenecks.description: Inadequate communication and public outreach to educate people about aging research and why it is important to study it.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of regulatory framework and template studies targeting aging in humans
bottlenecks.description: Time and cost involved is huge. Not enough candidates which fall in safe-accessible category.

bottlenecks.title: Data accessibility
bottlenecks.description: Unpublished raw data or difficulty with different formats

bottlenecks.title: Sample sourcing
bottlenecks.description: Relatively limited availability of healthy aged donors, as well as lack of human embryonic data

bottlenecks.title: Limited reach via publications
bottlenecks.description: Most high impact journals don't quite understand the field and therefore don't publish quality manuscripts in this area.

bottlenecks.title: Limited supply of geriatric mice
bottlenecks.description: Aged mice from JAX are expensive, while those from NIA rodent colony has a limit on the number and very old mice are few.

bottlenecks.title: Lifespan studies are long and expensive
bottlenecks.description: Often these studies cannot be done by a junior investigator with limited resources.

bottlenecks.title: Time
bottlenecks.description: Aging research in naturally aged mammals takes a long time to see the results.

bottlenecks.title: Risk
bottlenecks.description: Aging interventions are too risky. Funding programs prefer to support other kinds of research.

bottlenecks.title: heterogeneity
bottlenecks.description: People age and have dementia at different rates and respond differently to interventions

bottlenecks.title: unclear cause
bottlenecks.description: the real or combined cause of aging and dementia remain unclear which hinders the finding of a target medication

bottlenecks.title: data
bottlenecks.description: The dataset is not big enough or clean enough for data-driven research

bottlenecks.title: Collaboration with clinicians.
bottlenecks.description: Hard to establish and maintain.

bottlenecks.title: Reproducibility of data/results in the field
human gene set and environment control lifespan and healthspan
bottlenecks.description: Facts

bottlenecks.title: Misinformation
bottlenecks.description: Incentives are aligned for hype and personal gain

bottlenecks.title: Model organisms are too short-lived.
bottlenecks.description: We typically use short-lived model organisms to study aging, but there's a big problem - most models are short-lived pest specifies and if you don't want to spend the rest of your life on a single study, you kind of have to use them.  So we can extend lifespan several fold in yeast and invertebrates, but even doubling mouse lifespan becomes elusive.  We are therefore put into a position of either using short-lived species, or "breaking" homeostasis in long-lived species, which ultimately will only discover treatments idiosyncratic to the method of the break.

bottlenecks.title: Competitive nature of my field limits collaboration.
bottlenecks.description: Lots of duplication of effort and racing to be the "first".  Lifespan extension interventions can end up in Nature, failure to reproduce in more controlled studies end up buried in lower impact journals. (Not unique to aging - it just takes longer for us and wastes more time and effort).

bottlenecks.title: Aging is not really targeted in the clinic, rather, age-associated diseases are.
bottlenecks.description: This is pretty well-known.

bottlenecks.title: Ambiguous definition of cellular aging and cellular health.
bottlenecks.description: While organismal aging can be measured, cellular aging is not so well defined.

bottlenecks.title: Inaccurate published papers.
bottlenecks.description: Waste time; give people incorrect impressions.

bottlenecks.title: Over-hyping/over-promising
bottlenecks.description: Cause policymakers to invest in extremely high-risk/over-hyped research, rather than things more likely to succeed.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of regulatory path for medicines in this area
bottlenecks.description: Can't do lifespan studies in humans; need to translate medicines that block aging mechanisms to particular age-related disorders, which may be a challenge.  Regulatory agencies aren't used to preventative measures; hard to study.

bottlenecks.title: Talent
bottlenecks.description: We need many more talented people as the problem (aging) is very difficult to solve

bottlenecks.title: heterogeneous disease states
bottlenecks.description: potential masking of omics/biomarker signals if we consider all-cause/broad category disease states eg dementia, CVD, diabetes. However, precise definitions reduces power and can also be difficult to carry out, especially with neuro-related traits

bottlenecks.title: multimorbidity
bottlenecks.description: looking at age-related disease outcomes in isolation (what is typically done in research) is somewhat naive but the temporal nature of disease progression complicates statistical modelling

bottlenecks.title: Confusion around the definition of aging
bottlenecks.description: People disagree, mean different things when talking about it to each other, focus on different sub aspects

bottlenecks.title: Poor biomarkers that reflect core causes of aging, difficult to use, expensive
bottlenecks.description: Demonstrating a biomarker truly relates to aging depends on the definition of aging, which is a problem. Epigenetic clocks are the closest thing we have, they are still controversial.

bottlenecks.title: Length of time for lifespan studies in mammals
bottlenecks.description: Mammals live a long time

bottlenecks.title: Animal models
bottlenecks.description: The problem is to have more then just aged mice to work with. We need more then just aged black 6 mice that are commercially available, also rats, and new unknown aging models that have not been used.

bottlenecks.title: Aged human tissue, cells, organs
bottlenecks.description: We all know that animal models are not great, so working with human tissues would be great but getting is expensive, difficult, time consuming. Brain banks for the study of Alzheimer therapies (or other brain diseases) can show us the way. They are a dedicated resource that is cheap and easy to use. No specific additional ethical approval is necessary, no time-consuming collection is necessary and sharing is great.

bottlenecks.title: Aging-specific data collection
bottlenecks.description: One place that is open source and free where you can share aging relevant data sets.

bottlenecks.title: Aging biomarkers
bottlenecks.description: Hard to discover anti-aging interventions without accurate, high throughput, and biologically relevant biomarkers.

bottlenecks.title: In vivo assays
bottlenecks.description: Besides lifespan, which takes too long, there are few established assays researchers can use to test their candidate rejuvenating interventions.

bottlenecks.title: People
bottlenecks.description: More people should work on this

bottlenecks.title: easy access to aged models in the genetically heterogeneous background
bottlenecks.description: Aging animals in the lab is expensive and time-consuming, and represents the main limiting factor

bottlenecks.title: Most of the current knowledge is restricted to males, sex-pooled or sex-unlabeled data
bottlenecks.description: AGing differs strongly as a function of sex, and it's unclear what portion of currently accepted hallamarks/processe are conserved across sexes due to the bias in data generation

bottlenecks.title: An fast and generally acceptable readout of aging
bottlenecks.description: there are many hallmarks of aging, and it's hard to claim a pro-aging or rejuvenation without showing changes in multiple hallmarks.

bottlenecks.title: Investigating aging as a whole and not single symptoms
bottlenecks.description: I would love to know if there is a cellular seed of aging, but it is hard to investigate as molecular biologist as so many pathways are involved and all are interconnected. Hen and egg problem.

bottlenecks.title: I'm in academic research, so of course one of the biggest bottlenecks is funding.
bottlenecks.description: The best studies whose data can be mined for a long time require a lot of samples/subjects over time and cross-sectionally. The preparation and maintenance of a useable database for this information also requires skilled and long-term commitment.

bottlenecks.title: In academic research, another issue is that our reward system for labor (publication, funding, status improvement) usually requires staying on the same project for an extended period of time, with luck and skilled researchers on your side. If something fails, or it becomes evident that it will not succeed quickly, there remains a lot of systemic motivation to stick with the project, since precious funds and time have gone into starting it. However, this limits researchers' ability to jump to a project that may be more fruitful, and traps them in a slog that is financially costly. For young/female/POC researchers especially, losing time means losing a lot of career advancement opportunities.
Automation and AI :
bottlenecks.description: to faster the pace of innovation and reduce the cost to enter the field we need first more automation; It will reduce human labor (time/cost) towards experimentations, thus producing less biased data and results. combined with AI we get predictive models and limit the amount of  trials for instance;

bottlenecks.title: Legislation and Funding :
bottlenecks.description: ethics and rules are against aging companies for now; VCs and funds are still skeptical on investing in risky and long terms start up projects

bottlenecks.title: Education and Bridge Organizations :
bottlenecks.description: We need more advocates towards longevity and more people from different backgrounds to come up with new ideas for the field.

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: High-risk funding is short/insufficient to cover dedicated personnel and aging projects are long.

bottlenecks.title: Accepted surrogate outcomes
bottlenecks.description: There are no standard measures that are accepted as reflective of aging, other than mortality (rodents or humans)

bottlenecks.title: Data
bottlenecks.description: Many people try their own longevity interventions, but no data are collected

bottlenecks.title: market failure- interventions that are promising in the lab cant be translated to humans
bottlenecks.description: despite increase in knowledge the incidence of obesity is going up- we are up against corporations that do not optimize for human health. There are no incentives to improve human health- but there are to make them sick and treat them. A number of promising treatments that would be safe fall under supplements - only NIH supports that research but not pharma as there is no money to make

bottlenecks.title: Getting quantitative (mathematics/physics/complex systems) people thinking about longevity
bottlenecks.description: Gerontology has primarily been dominated by biological and hence been mostly driven by reductionist thinking. We need to be accepting of different perspectives and open to new hypotheses.

bottlenecks.title: Fellowship and funding awareness for young students and researchers
bottlenecks.description: Conferences and meetings need to provide opportunities for young talent to resonate with the mission. This will help people think about longevity as a tractable problem to work on.

bottlenecks.title: Ethical and regulatory concerns around longevity specific drugs and therapies need to become accessible
Inaccurate understanding of why we age
Failure to recognize that aging is programmed
Translating lab discoveries into therapies
bottlenecks.description: Lack of understanding of how to commercialize lab discoveries

bottlenecks.title: Reproducibility across labs and model organisms
bottlenecks.description: Idiosyncratic variations between different research groups and model organisms

bottlenecks.title: Collaborations between industry, academia, and VC
heterogeneity of how aging is manifested in each individual in a population
the length of time required for the research
aging encompasses many physiological changes, some in opposing manners in different cells / tissues
Aging is not an FDA approval indication
Funding

bottlenecks.title: Number and range of genotypes and species of mammals available for testing interventions
bottlenecks.description: Many promising leads take years to follow-up, and replicate.  One genotype of mouse (the usual) is not sufficient to make reasonable predictions about safety or efficacy in humans.

bottlenecks.title: Find the ideal cohort
bottlenecks.description: It's difficult to find an ideal cohort that include all the variables of interest, including the omics data, phenotypes data, function data, exposures data (ex: family history, education history, neighborhood, environment, life styles),  being followed up longitudinally. It would be the best to have such a cohort, although it's unlikely to get one.

bottlenecks.title: Translate from research to the real-world
bottlenecks.description: There are many wonderful researchers, but only few of them are able to change the real world based on their findings.

bottlenecks.title: Freedom of switching topics
bottlenecks.description: Current system encourage people to focus on one single topic, and rooms of switching topics may help people to expand the collaboration across different perspectives

bottlenecks.title: Research confined to a few discrete approaches in the NIA.
bottlenecks.description: Traditional focus of NIH institutions

bottlenecks.title: Insufficient time to conduct my primary research studies
bottlenecks.description: Massive administrative duties and burdens

bottlenecks.title: Bureaucratic regulations and restrictions specific to NIH IRP investigators
Funding is not sufficient
bottlenecks.description: obvious

bottlenecks.title: Insufficient emphasis on biology of aging as opposed to engineering, trials
bottlenecks.description: Aging biology is insufficiently understood.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of diverse mammalian/human in-vitro/ex-vivo systems that replicate/retain relevant aspects of aging
bottlenecks.description: We have no scalable platform to screen against aging/rejuvenation

bottlenecks.title: Cognitive health
bottlenecks.description: There exists few diagnostic and remedies for cognitive decline

bottlenecks.title: Data in human
bottlenecks.description: Its hard to have long human longitudinal studies and data from other model organisms are not applicable.

bottlenecks.title: Unnecessary arguments
bottlenecks.description: The field is stuck with if aging is a disease or not, instead of spending time on the real biology and computational aspects of it.

bottlenecks.title: Individual island
bottlenecks.description: Sometimes i feel like we are not using the experiences od other fields such as single cell community or developmental biology

bottlenecks.title: Viable regulatory path for aging medicines
bottlenecks.description: Would increase funding in the space

bottlenecks.title: Good models for age related indications
bottlenecks.description: to improve the likelyhood that animal models will translate to humans

bottlenecks.title: Sufficient funding for age related research
bottlenecks.description: To lower the barrier to entry for 1) non-experts, or 2) experts that have a concept

bottlenecks.title: No good definition of how to assess aging at a cellular level for high throughput in vitro work
bottlenecks.description: I think -omics based cellular/molecular biomarkers like epigenetic and transcriptomic analyses are great, but it would be fantastic if there were also high throughput techniques to study aging as a function of holistic cellular health and function.

bottlenecks.title: Current approaches for methylation clock analysis are expensive with slow turnaround, although hopefully wider-scale adoption of TIME-seq and similar methods will help
Not enough time
bottlenecks.description: I have a lot of research idea that I could do it, but I have not enough time to complete them, only a few ones.

bottlenecks.title: Not enough staff
bottlenecks.description: I need much more expert data scientists who would work on my projects

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: More funding is needed especially for high-risk projects

bottlenecks.title: Few consortia devoted to aging research
bottlenecks.description: There are few large consortia that are devoted to aging research particularly from a molecular biomarker perspective

bottlenecks.title: Need to train more interdisciplinary scientists
bottlenecks.description: Aging and the solutions for it are complex and intertwine many fields. Few places offer the needed interdisciplinary training

bottlenecks.title: Too much noise in the field / unreliable information.
Funding
bottlenecks.description: I have the amount I'd expect for the stage that I'm at and it's nothing systemic, funding is just almost always a bottleneck

bottlenecks.title: Recognition
bottlenecks.description: Also a general bottleneck for early-stage startups so not unique. Helped immensely by my connection to Ichor

bottlenecks.title: Contracted study timing
bottlenecks.description: Another general and inevitable bottleneck, but it quite literally is the bottleneck to accelerating my progress at this moment

bottlenecks.title: Understand batch effects between different studies
Publishing
