bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: too much appeal to authority logical fallacy - rich get richer

bottlenecks.title: Time per iteration/experiment
bottlenecks.description: Aging mice or even primary human cells takes time, reducing the experiments I can perform in a given time period

bottlenecks.title: Not enough researchers --> lower experimental output and/or quality of experiments performed (due to overextension or burnout)
bottlenecks.description: each researcher is our lab end up having a growing pile of projects as there's not enough people to carry them out. More researchers in aging would mean more experiments/projects pursued and better data quality

bottlenecks.title: Translational therapeutics and epidemiological studies
bottlenecks.description: Need more research done on how we can actually turn the discoveries we have into potential treatments that could be used in humans. Drug discovery, diet manipulations, etc., so that we can begin studying those effects. Also, there are many changes we can make in society that would drastically increase lifespan and we need to be studying those from a sociological/epidemiological POV, might make more impact than basic research in the near future

bottlenecks.title: More collaboration to work with multiple model organisms
bottlenecks.description: Pro-longevity findings hold more promise if they can be repeated in multiple animals. If a paper is published in C. elegans, there should be more avenues for that work to be picked up in flies/mice to see if similar mechanisms hold, and this work should be done as a collaboration between groups

bottlenecks.title: Hallmarks/biomarkers of aging
bottlenecks.description: We have to have ways to measure of anti-aging therapies work in higher organisms that doesn't rely on lifespan alone, or else we will never be able to do human trials without taking 50 years!

bottlenecks.title: A reliable and cost-effective biomarker of aging in different tissues.
bottlenecks.description: Current methods to gauge aging are either hard to reproduce or very expensive.

bottlenecks.title: Hard to get access to mammalian models that are closer to humans.
There is no map between model organism and humans, so most studies don't apply to us.
bottlenecks.description: Most research are not repeatable, and don't translate into therapeutics because we're fundamentally different.

bottlenecks.title: While it is well documented that lifestyle data matters, most research efforts are focused on looking for therapeutic pathways.
bottlenecks.description: People want to know what to do today, without giving value to key biometric data, people are left pray to the supplement industry, buying all kinds of supplements for longevity, most of these supplements haven't been proven for humans yet.

bottlenecks.title: We're entering the longevity hype cycle, where many people are assuming that we're a few years away from a great breakthrough.
bottlenecks.description: Just like AI, just like the internet, just like crypto, after the hype comes the winter; if we're not careful, we might lose the momentum due to people not managing their expectation properly.

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: Valley of death in startups is tough to overcome, especially for scientists and entrepreneurs in aging who are at a younger stage compared to others in biotech

bottlenecks.title: Team Building
bottlenecks.description: Somewhat due to funding, but tough to bring traditional pharma executives into early startups.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of scientific debate and discourse.
bottlenecks.description: Because it leads to unrealistic expectations and efforts that will not slow or reverse aging.

bottlenecks.title: low throughput of intervention testing
bottlenecks.description: I am a proponent of functionally-relevant readouts when evaluating putative aging interventions. In other words, I want to see obvious health improvements; molecular and cellular data (including clocks) are less convincing. Unfortunately, this requires in vivo testing, which is low throughput, particularly if phenotypes take months/years to manifest. This limits the number of interventions that can be tested.

bottlenecks.title: translational relevance of preclinical models
bottlenecks.description: This is by no means limited to aging research, but is sometimes ignored in aging research more than in other fields. Yeast, worms, flies, and mice are not humans, and there is no guarantee that the mechanisms that extend healthspan/lifespan in those species will have a meaningful effect in humans. This is particularly problematic for mice, because longevity results in mice often garner the most excitement, but mouse aging profiles and causes of death are very different from humans, making me highly skeptical of the translational relevance of the results.

bottlenecks.title: lack of gold standard readouts
bottlenecks.description: Virtually any aspect of biology can be connected to aging, so the field lacks cohesion. If you go to an aging conference you'll hear 30 interesting talks, but they will be unrelated to each other, using different models, different interventions, and different readouts. For each species, there should be an agreed-upon set of criteria for determining if an intervention has modified aging, similar to how teratoma formation is the gold standard for determining pluripotency. Without such standards, researchers can cherry pick the assays that "work" and ignore the rest, leading to 1) spurious results, and 2) the lack of common language, hindering progress.

bottlenecks.title: Obtaining aged human and animal samples. For ex aged mice on Jax are several hundred dollars each
Accurate a complete biomarker data sets like the proprietary one that BioAge has
Companies
bottlenecks.description: There aren't enough companies worldwide

bottlenecks.title: Media
bottlenecks.description: Media coverage is always toward immortality and stuff

bottlenecks.title: Translation of basic research
bottlenecks.description: Not enough funding

bottlenecks.title: Lack of novel mechanisms to prevent aging
studies take too long
bottlenecks.description: measuring lifespan takes too long; it's hard to measure aging rates instead of lifespan itself

bottlenecks.title: studies are low throughput and consequently underpowered
bottlenecks.description: wet-lab biology is phenomenally slow without automation; mice are expensive

bottlenecks.title: mice has low translational validity
bottlenecks.description: mice aren't humans; alternatives (i.e., human organoids) are expensive and complex

bottlenecks.title: The studies by definition are very long-term
Longitudinal studies would be very helpful bu hard to get funded
Lab space
bottlenecks.description: Acute shortage of lab space in the UK as supply catches up with demand (e.g. due to 2021 biotech boom)

bottlenecks.title: 10X Genomics consumables
bottlenecks.description: A powerful new technology but with a powerful new price tag. Our largest single cost item.

bottlenecks.title: Cell lines of different ages
bottlenecks.description: We rely on procuring panels of cell lines to help create the tools that guide our search for rejuvenation biology. It can take months to collect comprehensive panels, time that could be better spend making scientific progress.

bottlenecks.title: access to reasonable aging cohorts
bottlenecks.description: Takes too long to get an aged cohort from the start. You get the funding for projects and try to cobble together some sort of decentralized experiment where mice, dogs etc are included in trials across a highly heterogeneous set of backgrounds (different labs, people pets), which makes it already difficult aging-specific signatures even more difficult to detect reliably

bottlenecks.title: lack of understanding of novelty in the investment community
bottlenecks.description: There seems to be an understanding that 5 pathways are sufficient in our understanding of aging and how to tackle it. Epigenetics information loss, Nutrient signaling (MTOR, Sit) Inflammation, protein homeostasis, and people feel as though these lanes are full and there is not many new radically novel findings outside of the big players. You already have billions Altos, Calico being poured into very strong teams working on the problems so it's hard as a young upstart to be taken with credibility.

bottlenecks.title: Understanding the underline biology of aging and identifying drug-able targets
bottlenecks.description: I believe beyond liftstyle intervention we will eventually need therapeutics to meaningfully extend health span.

bottlenecks.title: Better quality data on the personalized aging drivers
bottlenecks.description: Everyone age differently. Identifying individual's risk factors would support precision medicine.

bottlenecks.title: Evidence based clinical research and regulatory pathway
bottlenecks.description: We need carefully and cleverly designed clinical trial to provide evidence of risk/benefit of potential therapeutics

bottlenecks.title: Regulatory cost
bottlenecks.description: Previously, we were unable to raise sufficient funds to test a medical device due to the excessive cost in testing relative to the size of the immediate addressable market. We were told it would take up to $25 million to bring the device to market.

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: Funding in the longevity space from both VCs and government grants is much more limited than other funding areas (e.g. cancer)

bottlenecks.title: Small talent pool
bottlenecks.description: Hard to find longevity-specific talent

bottlenecks.title: Insufficient understanding of the underlying mechanisms
bottlenecks.description: Aging is multi-multi-mlulti factorial and a super complex process

bottlenecks.title: Aging is a long process and that makes clinical studies difficult, and animal studies of a low translational value.
large and clean datasets across all omics of diverse cohorts
Fundamental
bottlenecks.description: Aging is inevitable. There's a direct correlation between improving quality of life and increasing lifespan. The interplay between these two is not defined well enough. This goes deeper into the question of immortality and what we, as researchers, want to achieve in the end.

bottlenecks.title: Good models for aging
bottlenecks.description: Aging hallmarks might be defined, but a good model that recapitulates all of these hallmarks is either missing or not consistent. In addition, many of these hallmarks are shared with other diseases. In the end, aging can be defined as the accumulation and predisposition of different diseases.

bottlenecks.title: Simpler and cheaper methods
bottlenecks.description: In order for us to fully characterise aging, we need to both show biological and chronological phenotypes in our models. Currently most methods for chronological phenotypes, such as DNA methylation and epigenetic clocks, are expensive and not that straightforward.

bottlenecks.title: human-centric models of aging
bottlenecks.description: animal models are useful but ultimately have different mechanisms and we are missing a lot as a field relying solely on those

bottlenecks.title: convincing theory of aging
bottlenecks.description: all current theories are speculative and do not provide a reliable roadmap to create impactful research programmes

bottlenecks.title: biomarkers of aging
bottlenecks.description: again, there is no clarity how to monitor aging trajectories in humans, especially for short term interventions

bottlenecks.title: Reliable translatable model systems
bottlenecks.description: The field lack reliable in vivo mammalian models to assay life span in a timely manner

bottlenecks.title: Often scientists focus on one hallmark of aging even though multiple hallmarks needed to be targeted
bottlenecks.description: Focusing on one hallmark may not be sufficient to achieve whole-animal longevity

bottlenecks.title: Bureaucracy
bottlenecks.description: Immigration bureaucracy

bottlenecks.title: Short term funding
bottlenecks.description: Time spent applying for funding

bottlenecks.title: Insufficient funding
bottlenecks.description: Researcher salaries in academia insufficient to make a living in high cost cities

bottlenecks.title: Lack of researchers talking to the public
bottlenecks.description: The longevity community is very inward facing. Count up the number of appearances of most longevity researchers, and you'll see they are at longevity conferences, on longevity podcasts, on longevity youtube channels, etc. Sinclair and ADG are rare exceptions. Aside from that you have some science communicators trying to move the needle (e.g. Andrew Steele, Sheekey, Brad Stanfield).

bottlenecks.title: Bystander effect among longevity community + lack of organization
bottlenecks.description: Those not working for or a part of a longevity organization (profit, non-profit, or research), are passive consumers of information with little sense of responsibility. Small groups that are highly motivated and well organized can have outsized effects. This is a problem that has to be solved from both sides or it fails to produce any momentum. An organized effort with a lack of activation of individuals is inert, and an activated community with no direction flounders.

bottlenecks.title: Distilled messages
bottlenecks.description: Well organized movements have powerful and pithy messages- single line arguments that are easy to understand, are compelling, and which are supported with a myriad of stories and examples. I think the longevity movement is largely missing this. Some individuals who regularly give presentations have some messages mastered, but the broader community is unable to articulate the why, let alone the how, which means they will be ineffective as outward facing ambassadors of this space and which will lead them to simply communicating with those who already believe.

bottlenecks.title: Models of aging (cells/animals)
bottlenecks.description: Studies take a long time (ie 3 years for mice)

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: Success rates for grants are around 5-10% in Australia

bottlenecks.title: Aging biomarkers
bottlenecks.description: Do current biomarkers accurately represent aging (eg epigenetic clocks)

bottlenecks.title: Biomarkers
bottlenecks.description: Because we need earlier signals that interventions work and don't have time or money to wait for patients to die when measuring lifespan changes.

bottlenecks.title: Damage cleanup
bottlenecks.description: We already know families of molecules that cause problems (arterial plaques, brain plaques, lipofuscin, etc), where are the gene therapies to make enzymes that clean this stuff up?

bottlenecks.title: model systems w high clinical validity
bottlenecks.description: screens for SASP & life extension in model organisms don't get us at the mechanisms of aging

bottlenecks.title: lack of detailed multi-omic longitudinal studies
bottlenecks.description: post-diagnosis studies do not reveal multi-causal initiators of aging-related diseases

bottlenecks.title: clinical endpoints
bottlenecks.description: need surrogate endpoints beyond time to mortality to speed up intervention OODA loop

bottlenecks.title: funding
bottlenecks.description: i can only afford to have 5 projects going in parallel, whereas there are at least a dozen that i'd like to pursue

bottlenecks.title: too few exceptional scientists passionate about aging biology research
bottlenecks.description: possibly a marketing thing

bottlenecks.title: Extreme lack of automation of basic lab work.
bottlenecks.description: People don't scale; machines do.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of quick, accurate, low-cost models for testing of interventions.
bottlenecks.description: Large bureaucratic overhead burden on simple animal studies significantly slows R&D progress.

bottlenecks.title: Limited public and private capital for unconventional therapies.

Understanding the essence of aging.
Why it exists at the first place?
bottlenecks.description: Does nature invented such biological principles to prevent non functioning of a biological system after a certain threshold to maintain birth death homeostasis?

bottlenecks.title:
Interconnection among hallmarks of aging.
What is the relationship?
bottlenecks.description: Longevity industry to exist must identify these relationships to go from natural evolution to intelligent design principles to go beyond natural biology into engineered biology to enhance healthspan.

bottlenecks.title:
Tackling the root causes of aging to achieving Longevity.
How can it be done?
bottlenecks.description: Biology has become information. Computation and mathematics is applicable. So data will enable accelerating simulations of experimental clinical trails. Understanding from human model organisms at the core is key for Longevity industry. Just like a mobile phone, a digital extension of information, we might have a wearable mobile organ a biological extension of health instead of taking drugs, it will self generate biological therapeutics to enhance humans.

bottlenecks.title: Bad Reputation
bottlenecks.description: People associate longevity with charlatanism or transhumanism which brings fear.

bottlenecks.title: Low awareness
bottlenecks.description: The Public don't know what longevity research is, it's hard to grasp.

bottlenecks.title: Enormous Data
bottlenecks.description: Hard to have a strategic overview of the field and use the evergrowing available data.

bottlenecks.title: Clinical trials for anti aging drugs
Too few explorational grant opportunities
bottlenecks.description: Misalignment of incentives (+ see below)

bottlenecks.title: Too few grants outside of NIH/NCI for non-traditional PIs. Leads to steep competition (I.e. Impetus virtually impossible to get)
bottlenecks.description: Space/vertical is small

bottlenecks.title: More radical and risky ideas (rejuvenation/reprogramming) are difficult to get funding for
bottlenecks.description: Public/financier perception, bias towards traditional biotech - even for longevity focused VCs

bottlenecks.title: Not enough like-minded, capable and financially secured people in the industry (to work together)
bottlenecks.description: It's always such a blast to meet such a person! All the work starts to move forward exponentially. We come across these people too seldom (but to be fair it's getting better every year).

bottlenecks.title: The best life science now (not longevity in particular but biology/medicine/chemistryâ€¦ in general) is being done within unsuited (for life extension ideas) economical structures. Even if we stay within free market what would be the derivatives (financial instruments) in favor of life extension? What are the agents acting accordingly? As a result there is a scarcity of resources for our cause, people are fighting rather than collaborating. We only see human nature at its worse now.
bottlenecks.description: I'm not sure I can fit it in one paragraph, it's a topic for the whole book.

bottlenecks.title: Personal medical data access is over-protected and overall there's too much fuss and hysteria around it. People are only talking about its protection but not the harm that the lack of its disclosure is causing.
bottlenecks.description: So many great projects in organized biohacking, self-organized clinical trials, data storage and share, human biomarkers research has stagnated. We could have had much needed open anonymized big clinical data already! As community-builders we too could have been using these platforms, they being great welcoming tool for the new people in the field.

bottlenecks.title: money
bottlenecks.description: not enough money from NIA and it's hard to recruit/train/retain people (and do research)

bottlenecks.title: time
bottlenecks.description: not enough time for research

bottlenecks.title: people
bottlenecks.description: harder to recruit/retain people

bottlenecks.title: Studies completed
bottlenecks.description: A lot of studies depend on time. For now, we have a limited number of studies, and it takes time to have more.

bottlenecks.title: Access to aged mice resources
bottlenecks.description: In the US, NIA colonies have limiited availability (usually prioritized for NIA-funded grantees).

bottlenecks.title: Somewhat of a stigmatism against focusing exclusively on extending maximum longevity in humans - with the more palatable 'healthspan' being offered as somewhat of a (in my opinion) compromise or buffer.
bottlenecks.description: Not sure why exactly extending lifespan is seen as not a worthy goal of pursuit.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of clinical trials with aging as a target outcome.
bottlenecks.description: Probably a lack of good biomarkers to measure aging phenotypes, possibly the fact that aging itself may not be strictly classified as a 'disease' to be treated.

bottlenecks.title: biomarker for aging in mice
bottlenecks.description: somewhere to send off tissue/blood to test if an intervention is working

bottlenecks.title: access to human tissue
bottlenecks.description: expensive, time-consuming, limited tissue types, limited health data

bottlenecks.title: Highly innovative, risky, or exploratory research. Research that could fail, but that is worth the risk in order to discover breakthroughs
bottlenecks.description: Conservative funding agencies

bottlenecks.title: Open research: sharing data, samples, and results freely with the community
bottlenecks.description: Academic incentives to publish, private incentives to profit

bottlenecks.title: Novel aging interventions, combinations of interventions
bottlenecks.description: More groups starting to try combos, finally, but there hasn't been anyone or any agency willing to fund such a study in the traditional settings. Funding and structures lacking for basic exploratory research and efforts to glean insights from other areas of science or engineering and apply those to aging. Not enough reward for looking outside the lamppost; non-traditional ideas.

bottlenecks.title: open access datasets available for profit / industry use
bottlenecks.description: many datasets forbid use in commercial applications

bottlenecks.title: data that measure aging across all platforms (DNAm, plasma proteins, physiology, phenotypes, etc) in every single subject
bottlenecks.description: it's expensive

bottlenecks.title: There are not enough systemic approaches being followed
bottlenecks.description: Most companies follow the standard biotech/pharma model of developing a single molecule

bottlenecks.title: I feel there is not enough focus on the brain.
bottlenecks.description: Being physically (cranium) and molecularly (BBB) shielded makes developing treatments for the CNS much harder

bottlenecks.title: Regulatory agencies do not consider ageing as an indication to develop drugs against
Public knowledge of longevity
bottlenecks.description: Longevity biotech field is extremely confusing and unapproachable for the average person.

bottlenecks.title: heterogeneity of age related disease outcome and difficulty to find animal models
Deathist culture
bottlenecks.description: Aging is not considered a priority (barely even on the list) for our civilization. Resources and manpower are correspondingly scarce. Healthcare regulations and markets do not facilitate longevity oriented products/services.

bottlenecks.title: Short-termist thinking
bottlenecks.description: Even within the longevity community, most people are looking for "long hanging fruit" that doesn't exist - rather than doing the necessary difficult research and technology development

bottlenecks.title: Artisanal science institutions
bottlenecks.description: R&D is mostly still done following century old methods of manual labor and hypothesis and publications ridden with narrative fallacy. Our institutions and funding are setup to maintain it this way. We need to switch to automation, massive empirical data collection, and computational modeling.

bottlenecks.title: A lack of good tools for measuring aging and the impact of any interventions.
bottlenecks.description: Since interventional lifespan studies in humans are largely impractical the field needs to show that interventions have positive benefit. Currently we are forced to target diseases the FDA recognizes. This is ok initially but will prevent us for actually tackling aging head on.

bottlenecks.title: No clear understanding of what really drives aging. The field really only understands bits and pieces.
bottlenecks.description: Without truly understanding these processes, the field largely stumbles around in the dark.

bottlenecks.title: Due largely to the bottlenecks above, there is no clear regulatory path for a true aging therapeutic. Even as we ameliorate those, a concerted lobbying effort will likely be required to sway the regulators.
bottlenecks.description: This will be required to make aging/longevity therapeutics reimbursable and available broadly.

bottlenecks.title: Not enough aging data
bottlenecks.description: Most experiments are done for two conditions, and typically they do not track age

bottlenecks.title: Not enough longitudinal aging data for healthy human patients
bottlenecks.description: Typically, we have data for critically ill patients or cadavers. Whereas, for aging research, we need more longitudinal data for health patients who seldom regularly visit a doctor

bottlenecks.title: Overhyped claims, irreproducibility of major results in the field
bottlenecks.description: Typically, the results for anti-aging effects are irreproducible, or show minor effects. The quality standards are low. Most of the available results are typically trash. Negative results are not being published at all.

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: more research

bottlenecks.title: Lab space
bottlenecks.description: more research

bottlenecks.title: good students/postdocs
bottlenecks.description: more research

bottlenecks.title: Hype
bottlenecks.description: Longevity is the hype now, and many longbio startups don't amount to anything, beyond catchy buzzwords (akin to the ICO era of crypto)

bottlenecks.title: Regulatory non-recognition of aging
bottlenecks.description: While there is some movement in this front, overall, having to rely on age-associated orphan diseases is a major hurdle

bottlenecks.title: Lack of representation in media
bottlenecks.description: There are many great media communicators in the space, but it's not enough - longevity biotech needs a widespread ideology change. Meanwhile, most popular media (shows, movies, games) that feature long life and/or immortality do so in a negative context (ultra-rich being immortal, overpopulation, crazy egotistical characters, etc). Consequently, most people (incl. high profile like Elon Musk in a recent tweet) have an unfavorable view of the field

bottlenecks.title: High-caliber entrepreneurs with sufficient technical knowledge of drug discovery best practices
bottlenecks.description: There is no shortage of aging research that can be translated to a business and R&D plan today. Barring the recent exceptional downturn in biopharma markets, there is no shortage of interested investors. But these two resources are abundant because not enough individuals are positioned to translate that promising science to business, meaning the source of NewCos has not been fully mined and there are relatively few investment options in the space still

bottlenecks.title: Discussing/marketing "longevity" is challenging
bottlenecks.description: The definition of "longevity" in the minds of those working in longevity medicine/science compared to the definition in the mind of the public is totally different.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of clinical trials
bottlenecks.description: No defined endpoints/lack of funding

bottlenecks.title: Lack of reproducibility
bottlenecks.description: Most of experiments are done by one group and it is too expensive/lack of novelty to repeat.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of standards in the field
bottlenecks.description: Most of the groups choose their own markers of healthspan, they are different between different model organisms, etc.

bottlenecks.title: US trade war with China
bottlenecks.description: Inhibits the ability to conduct research at scale

bottlenecks.title: Lack of translational models
bottlenecks.description: Worms and flies do not age the same ways humans do

bottlenecks.title: Funding dedicated specifically to aging
bottlenecks.description: It is easier to allocate funding to disease-related projects

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: Work and live in Ireland, funding is difficult for basic science

bottlenecks.title: Skepticism
bottlenecks.description: Work on bats, difficult as they are non-model organisms

bottlenecks.title: Lack of technical resources
bottlenecks.description: Work on bats, there is a lack of resources  as they are non-model organisms

bottlenecks.title: Too many confounding factors for aging
Not being known or recognized by those who could benefit from my skills and knowledge
bottlenecks.description: All the work I have been doing for clients for long is confidential and as such not publicly available. Therefore I have no visible credentials other than occasional discussions on various longevity groups throughout the years. As a result many people that could benefit from my skills are unaware of my skills and expertise if they even know that I exist. The people that are aware of my skills are mainly people that hang around on various longevity groups and have read some of my writings there throughout the years. These people are not the high level people in the industry that have money and power.

bottlenecks.title: Capital
bottlenecks.description: So I can dedicate more time to creating content that is out in the open and beneficial for the public as well as those in the industry

bottlenecks.title: Financial independence
bottlenecks.description: Financial independence is of course just a longer term dream but if I were financially independent I would mostly refuse to do any work that only benefits a select few that pay me instead of being publicicly available for all to benefit.

bottlenecks.title: no existing network with other scientists working in aging research
Funding
bottlenecks.description: to finance my aging research I have to support other research for which I get easily funding

bottlenecks.title: Finding candidates that combine the scientific expertise and business acumen
bottlenecks.description: little talent on the market, no central talent pool

bottlenecks.title: Having proper scientific evidence (e.g. for offered supplements, medication, etc.)
bottlenecks.description: difficult tondo a randomized trial on longevity, science overall still very young field, aging is not considered a disease

bottlenecks.title: Overcoming hurdle of customer conviction
bottlenecks.description: Aging is not considered a disease, science is young, longevity community is a bubble which leads to overestimating awareness outside of bubble

bottlenecks.title: Financing
bottlenecks.description: never enough money!

bottlenecks.title: Regulatory
bottlenecks.description: Requirements for functional outcomes (as opposed to surrogates) before approval is limiting

bottlenecks.title: 4 year NIH grant cycles
bottlenecks.description: Mouse aging studies can take 5 to 7 years

bottlenecks.title: cost and access to mass-spec proteomics
People
bottlenecks.description: There is a serious lack of qualified people working on the right problems.  Most people in the field work on the wrong problems, but there is comparatively not even very many working on those vs other fields. Aging interventional research is just starting to claw its way out of being a backwater

bottlenecks.title: Lack of understanding of the fundamental processes that drive aging
bottlenecks.description: Aging is extremely complex.  It's very nature is the chaotic introduction of increasing disorder into a biological system with time.  Even if we did somehow understand the myriad components it would remain an exceptionally hard problem to solve, but we don't.  Best near term bet is to take from nature existing solutions that already exist and replace as much old diseased tissue as possible.

bottlenecks.title: Cost disease
bottlenecks.description: Human clinical research and to a lesser but still large extent, non human preclinical research has some of the most extreme forms of cost disease present in our civilization.  Clinical trials cost between 10-100x what human research studies could cost. Progress is thus 1/10th-1/100th what it could be.

bottlenecks.title: Fundings for fundamental research
bottlenecks.description: Less and less fundings are allocated to research in fundamental model systems, which precludes the emergence of new groups and projects, and eventually slows down the whole field.

bottlenecks.title: Dedicated equipment and resources
bottlenecks.description: Related to the above point, lack of fundings limits available dedicated equipment, but also the amount of (human) resources to interact with and build-up larger projects.

bottlenecks.title: lack of standards for biomedical data measurement, storage and sharing
bottlenecks.description: required for communication and analysis

bottlenecks.title: paywalls for access to scientific journals/papers
bottlenecks.description: research funded by public tax dollars should be open and available to the public.

bottlenecks.title: Lack of standard widely available analytical tools for discovery and in-silico hypothesis testing
bottlenecks.description: to more easily query data resources with statistical tools to search for insights

bottlenecks.title: Access to datasets
bottlenecks.description: I have significant academic biological / informatics background, but many of the most useful/comprehensive datasets are not easily publicly available or lack full annotation.

bottlenecks.title: Funding
bottlenecks.description: I'm an independent researcher currently working part time at a nonprofit, so I don't have funding dedicated to supporting working on primary aging research full time.

bottlenecks.title: Open science / collaborators
bottlenecks.description: See answer to next question below (forum)

bottlenecks.title: PI's don't really care about bringing in aging drugs
bottlenecks.description: artifact of academia. focused on publications. tenure track faculty have been programmed to repeat similar things.

bottlenecks.title: Not having access to everyone else's information/input flows/cognitive strengths and weaknesses. Ideally we WOULD have perfect information of EVERYONE'S INPUT FLOWS and get privacy-preserving AI to compare difs between people's infoflows to maximize speed
bottlenecks.description: so I best know what to optimally allocate my attention/strategy AND know what to do that's unique, what I'm best at, *and* where I can most easily recruit talent (from within my social group or from the rest of the world)

bottlenecks.title: Opportunities to pitch for investments
bottlenecks.description: I am looking for investors to support commercialisation of a technology.

bottlenecks.title: Networking
bottlenecks.description: It is difficult to get to know relevant players in my geographic location (London).

bottlenecks.title: Mentoring
bottlenecks.description: It would be great to know people with whom I can regularly discuss and learn from.

solutions.title: A culture of long-termism and optimism about maximizing human health and lifespan.
Wide scale perception change --> that obviating aging is a moral imperative.
The ability to inexpensively outsource longevity studies to CROs.
real metric to evaluate the biological age

Increased regulatory paths to getting longevity medicine to the market.
Either a special economic zone or a significant change in FDA policy allowing fundamental research in aging interventions to be clinically investigated

Resource that will help matching anti-aging startups with investors

Ability to work on (fund funding for) pathways outside the mainstream
Central facility for getting access to tissues of aged mammals from mice to humans., but needs to be easy.
Establishing a data standardization office, with impact on establishing collection and record protocols that generate good data
That negative results in the aging field are published and equally represented in comparison to positive results

established researchers to publically say aging can be cured in our lifetimes and that finding a cure should be a soceital priority

longer term grants that would give me time
Funding.
Quality assurance in academic centers.

More pipelines for independent research to impact the space. I think there are alot of people like me from non-academic backgrounds that are doing this type of work in silos and the field would benefit from there being mediums through which to present the ways that people outside of academia and even industry biotech are thinking about aging..
obtaining sustained funding
Aging job board
would be great if one site like AcademicLabs could show you all biopharma by their preclinical pipelines, specifically the indications and targets/pathways of interest, to help us tailor our pitches
My work is in Systems Bio modeling, and I turned it into an open-source project, Life123.science  .  Funding and more collaborators would make a difference
100X the VC funding to longevity startups and make it much easier to get warm intros to well matched VCs.

I think there can be an improvement around social perception of aging and futuristic technologies. Some topics are still thought of as taboo and makes it difficult to attract people and funding in the space.
Special FDA Regulatory group for aging focussed clinical trial
Deregulation of experimental technologies via the equivalent of the accredited investor option for early adopters who accept extreme high risk of experimental technologies.

Most of biotech still features PhDs and older-executives at the helm, and while I believe more experience is certainly important for a complex field such as biology, I wonder if there are other ways of showing 'scientific-capability' without having to do a PhD or MD.
I think more people caring about aging will drive more of everything else
Close collaboration with labs/individuals using modern cutting edge molecular, genetic and statistical approaches

At this point, we need to start studying various organism with different lifespan and see why certain organism live longer and what maybe causing it. We need to integrate all kind of "omics" study and beyond.
A consensus on the biological nature of aging
Mass media driven public awareness
Intelligent robotics to automate things.
Universal and reliable biomarker
lifespan measuring institute/company that uses a uniformed method

widespread acknowledgement of aging as a disease.

intermediary that does clinical trials of some sort for promising work from academia

delivery tools

streamlining access to the series large scale publicly funded longitudinal studies initiated by NHLBI and currently supported primarily by NIA (ARIC, CARDIA, MESA, CHS, Jackson Heart Study, Strong Heart Study, Bogalusa Heart Study)

Broader research participant databases -- I work in human neuroimaging. It takes a lot of time and work to find eligible participants. We are building our own database locally, but it has been hugely challenging.
resource
searchable and structured knowledge base for raw literature data
Acceptance of aging as an indication for FDA clinical trials

A consensus paper -- similar to the Hallmarks -- that describes a "gold standard" measure of aging (and provides evidence) OR a statement that we should all be highly specific and precise in our published definitions of aging (e.g., What time scale? What biological scale [cell vs organism]?) .
More awareness for the importance of the work we're doing.
A multi-billion dollar federal initiative dedicated to brain rejuvenation research
Having access to multiple large longitudinal studies with ease
NIA aged rodent colony

increased funding for fundamental research, especially long term funding (the typical 2-5 year funding cycle of NIH is insufficient to support aging studies, which by definition must extend over much longer time periods).
Capacity of study sections and NIH to fund research other than the prevailing paradigm.
Human Bone Marrow samples from yound and aged donors, healthy or with known condition
Definition of aging

innovation hub centred around bridging the gap between research and biotech (in the field of aging and longevity)
It would be a combination of the first and third, human age related samples with longitudinal data.
greater access to aged samples
Private (non-academia) support that is more geared toward exploration than profit.

For some of the structural obstacles I cannot propose a great solution unfortunately. For one of them I might suggest that there is a missed opportunity in having "outside the box" "not NiH-fundable" non-NIH funding mechanisms that are similar in size to the R01 mechanism, and that although the cost is non-trivial, if slight consideration is given to not only funding the researchers for the same projects that could/would have been funded by other mechanisms,  the impact from somethign like this could potentially be very very large.

One thing that would be really cool is some sort of centralized repository of aging research information. Everyone can contribute their knowledge (maybe through an incentive system to motivate people). As long as it is catalogued very well, I think something like this would be hugely beneficial (at least until the rise of artificial general intelligence).

Tool: A set of validated treatments that show, in cell or animal models, recapitulation of 80% or more of the epigenetic, transcriptomic and metabolomic changes with age.  Resource: A high resolution, single cell atlas of human aging across multiple tissues (starting from adolescence, and with high density in the 40s to 60s). Regulatory change: Right to prescribe and run trials on safe compounds for anti-aging interventions.
Multi-omic data of a longitudinal human cohort, with multiple time point

1. Flexibility of US Visa. H1-B and O-1 Visa are currently tied to an employer. 2. Financial freedom: Being able to work on different areas of longevity without being constrained by having to sustain living costs
More public and private funding in Europe
public outreach
Very streamlined/unified formatting and toolsets for aging sequencing data (Illumina chips are close, but probes are limited in their own way).
My lab would tremendously benefit from companies/cores offering lifespan, healthspan services.
The most significant positive impact on my work would be for aging to be seen socially as a disease. If so, research would advance globally as in many other fields, such as cancer research.
UK Biobank and clinical studies
don't know how to counteract misinformation
A long-lived animal where you could flip a switch and get an aged animal that perfectly recapitulates chronological aging phenotypes.

A social norm in aging research that researchers work together as a team, and publish as a team, rather than individual stars working in close-ish proximity but trying not to step on each other's toes and debating who gets to be first author.

better infrastructure and more research sponsored time

A platform that update the current progress/publications on the relevant topics of aging research.

I'd regulate the supplement industry, not to turn it into the FDA, but to get manufacturer to back their claims with studies and stop the fake marketing. I'd start a mapping initiatives to map rodents organisms with the human organism to help improve scientific research.
Lab space with other aging researchers
Grouping scientists who are greatest proponents with those who are harshest critiques of popular longevity approaches to have a constructive scientific debate.

Agreed-upon gold standard longevity readouts for each model organism (worms, flies, mice, rats) that make it easier to compare apples-to-apples for longevity studies. Something akin to "if you don't use this assay in your paper, you can't call it a longevity paper". And the readout shouldn't be lifespan, because 1) it's a crappy surrogate for health, 2) it is less likely to be translationally relevant than physiological readouts, 3) it takes forever.
Aged mice for testing biomarkers and potential clinical therapeutics
I am opening a funding platform for longevity companies
More money and interest in scientifically sound, translational research or companies
automated cell culture
a 10 year funding mechanism from NIH or industry
Rapid and quality supply of different cell types of different ages

A way to increase visibility of IP being generated, but not yet published at leading schools like harvard, starford. Like if you can talk to a bunch of grad students who have potentially awesome idea but don't quite know how to put a pitch deck, run the numbers and build out the operations and logistics arms of a company to make it actually commercially viable.
more clinical research and paving the way to regulatory clarity.
More longevity funding
Better tools and faster processes to recuruit volunteers for clinical studies.
funding for pilot projects

developing multiple biosensor that targets multiple hallmarks to study aging in vivo
Oprah
Society could make it even less of its business what I personally choose to work on (as long as I don't present a clear and present danger to another person)

Ideally, I would love to work in a research institute with sufficient resources to enable full focus on advancing research. It should optimally be located in multiple jurisdictions to avoid the need to immigrate, which wastes peoples time and money on ineffecient bureaucracy. Absolutely not to be located in a high-cost, high-inflation prone metropolitan area where increasingly only careers in commercial product development make any sense.

A thorough outward facing study on messaging to the public. Which terms quickly and effectively communicate info regarding this field? Which inspire credibility vs skepticism? Excitement vs caution/fear? Motivation vs apathy? What evidence quickly and easily supports our positions?
Unlimited money
More funding in the field, to drive up salaries would help me quit software engineering and move into bio tech.
stopping publishing 95% of papers and using machine-readable data formats instead; it's 2023 and it's ridiculous that I have to read 20+ papers to figure out what has and has not been replicated

a super-consent method of doing dangerous clinical trials: people could prove through, say, a monitored, detailed test, that they understand the risks and value proposition of the proposed clinical trial. this could allow risky, preventative-medicine trials without having to go into overseas jurisdictions, where there is worse infrastructure for patient monitoring.
The availability of GUI-driven, automated, basic lab tools and ethically cloned organs and tissues for studies.
Core foundation team of nin conventional executioner, researchers, engineers something like youngmind similar to deepmind.
A way to automatically synthetize the research and have a visualisation of it.

funding agency

A forum for sharing reproducible analyses of existing data beyond ad-hoc fashion (ex: highly trafficked and converging on shared work rather than low traffic), making data available, and discussing the conclusions rigorously (similar to highly used code on GitHub). (This would be helpful for all of science, not just aging! It likely needs critical mass of high quality work and probably moderation to do well.)
Working on outside the box research and importantly acceptance of "negative" results. Most scientific attempts fail and most results will be negative/no differences being found.
OBS Studio of everyone's workflows and then AI (esp gpt-index) to autocategorize/autosort it all
